name: No Guilt Caesar
headline: No Guilt Caesar
keywords: Vegetarian,American,Sauce Recipes,Salad Dressing Recipes,Tofu Recipes,Low-Carb,Low Sodium,Low Calorie,Diabetes-Friendly,Low-Cholesterol,Heart-Healthy,Low-Fat,Pureeing Recipes

recipeInstructions.text: Starting on the lowest speed, chop the cheese cubes in the blender jar until it settles into the bottom of the jar, gradually increasing the speed. Add the garlic down the chute and chop until minced.

Next, add the mustard, white wine vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, salt and pepper, and tofu to the blender and blend until smooth. While the blender is running, drizzle olive oil down the middle of the vortex that has formed. Add more or less of the olive oil and blend until it reaches salad dressing consistency.

review.reviewBody: I love, love. love. love, love this. I started with this as written, years ago, and have since modified it to my own tastes, or guest tastes, depending on the occasion. That's one of the things I've always loved about Alton - he brings the scientific food perfection and then let's you modify and personalize.
Hi Christine!! Here are my modifications:  Swap the vinegar for lemon juice.  Add 2 anchovies.  Delicious.

Yummy! I've been experimenting trying to make dressings with less fat, although this isn't the lowest in fat that I've found, it is very tasty! Although I'm not a vegetarian, I'm not sure if you could technically call this vegetarian because there are anchovies in Worcestershire sauce fyi.

I did a little FODMAPS version of this recipe, and it turned out great. I substituted caramelized green spring onions for the garlic, liquid aminos (to taste) for the Worcester Sauce, and put in white wine instead of vinegar. Totally amazing.
This is the best!!!

I have mixed feelings about this recipe.  I'd rate the flavor of the recipe as good but not great.  The recipe itself makes waay too much dressing, I'd definitely cut it in half.  I did add anchovy paste, as real caesar dressing should include this.  It's pretty garlicky, which I don't mind but some might.  Overall, I felt this was missing the right balance of flavors that a regular caesar dressing has, I just can't put my finger on what exactly is wrong or missing.
I added anchovies and lemon juice.  Delicious!
When I first tasted it, I thought it lacked something. I added 3 anchovies slices. It was almost perfect, just needed some lemon juice I think.

This turned out amazing!!  I truly do not like tofu (taste, but more so the texture, so I was really weary of it as an ingredient, but it really worked in this recipe!  For those non-tofu eating people like me, I learned that just plain "soft tofu" is also the same as "silken soft tofu."  I also added a dash of lemon juice, just because I like lemon juice.  I made this for a large crowd, and everyone couldn't believe this was "healthy."  It was a giant hit!

I love this salad dressing. It is creamy, garlicky and tasty. That being said, I added 1Tblsp lemon juice. My husband, who loves Wishbone salad dressing, ate two big plates of salad with this dressing. He loved it and I was very surprised.

I'd been searching for a good salad dressing recipe to make because I tired of the taste of store bought dressing. I was apprehensive about using tofu and was going to substitute it and use Greek yogurt as others suggested. However, I decided against that because I really try to prepare food for the first time, as the recipe indicates.  Of course, I couldn't tell there was tofu in the dressing. And, I LOVE garlic, which was a stand out flavor. So this was a WIN-WIN. Another great recipe, Alton. Thank you!
This is a fabulous lower fat/calorie dressing!! I didn't have tofu so I used Greek yogurt, I added about 1 Tbsp. of lemon juice and used extra garlic and Worcestershire. DE-LICIOUS!!!!

This is an awesome dressing! I've never written a review before although I've logged in and been saving recipes in My Recipe Box since circa 2002 LOL But this was so good that I wanted to tell Mr. Alton Brown YOU ROCK! And too bad no more Good Eats :(  BTW I used 1/2 cup of Trader Joe's organic firm tofu (the yellow package one and 1/2 cup water instead of silken tofu which I didn't have last night. It created the creamy silken tofu like texture. I'll use less Dijon next time like other reviewers are saying. Maybe my dijon mustard was too spicy ;

Another home run from Alton Brown- I would give this recipe 6 stars if I could! I used grated Parmesan, added an extra clove of garlic (because I like a garlicky Caesar, and an extra dash of Worcestershire. Next time I may thin it out with a bit of lemon juice, but over all this recipe makes a thick, luxurious Caesar dressing and you'd NEVER know that it didn't contain the traditional egg yolk and anchovies! This will certainly become a staple in my fridge and will get me eating my salads again :-
YUMMMY!!!!!!!! I used greek yogurt instead of the tofu and added a little agave syrup to cut the bite a little bit.... delicious!

This is GREAT!!! I thought I wouldn't be able to have Caeser dressing again since I became a health nut but now I can!!!! Thank god for silken tofu! It tastes wonderful and I don't miss a thing! Curious about how many calories are in it...
I could not believe this turned out as good as it did. When I read the recipe...I thought to myself, "no anchovies? no lemon? no egg?". But OMG it is fabulous!! Super easy to make, took a minute!

because alton is my hero!  the dressing had a pasty texture on my tongue. i think it may be related to the parmesan cheese (i used reggiano) and/or how my blender chopped it up. overall taste was okay, nothing to die for. i like ina's caesar but it has soooo much more fat and calories.  i was hoping this would have a similar taste.

This is one of the best Caesar dressings I've had.

There are vegetarian Worcestershire sauces available, I used one in this recipe.

I found this under the 'vegetarian' search, but worchestershire is not vegetarian because it contains anchovies. If you're making this recipe for a vegetarian, you may want to find an alternate ingredient.

I can't believe how delicious this is. I only used one garlic and it was a bit garlic-y for me, and I think I also used half the dijon. Still, I will definitely make this again and again. I didn't add a lot of oil and it had consistency of hummus, so I can see myself having this as a substitute for hummus with some pita. I also used it as a dip for grilled veggies. Thanks, Alton!

This is fantastic! Even my husband, who thinks I'm trying to poison him with "health food", loves this dressing. It has all the yummy characteristics of Caesar dressing. I add a bit of extra salt or if you really want to go authentic, add a bit of anchovy paste. (It's very inexpensive and comes in a tube. Save the rest for puttanesca.) This is a staple in our fridge.

I'm so thrilled to have found this recipe. It tastes great and is so creamy. My daughter is vegetarian and loves caesar salads. The tofu makes me happy because she gets protein and no anchovies makes her happy. It came out just a touch spicy so next time I'll try cutting back on the dijon mustard and try the lemon juice like others have suggested.

My 11 yr old daughter lives on salad, and loves my traditional Caesar dressing with the egg yolk and lots of EVOO. I tried this today, although I only had silken firm tofu. I added a little low sodium chicken broth to thin it out and...It was a WINNER! She loved it and I thought it was quite tasty too!

I read the reviews, tried the recipe, and everyone in the family gave it five stars!  I did add the juice of half a lemon.  It made 2 cups (16 oz) of dressing.  It tasted like a classic caesar dressing!  Way to go Alton!!

I have a friend who can never find that good restaurant quality dressing in the stores.  I loved this recipe so I made it.  After I told him there was tofu in it, he wasn't as pleased, but still enjoyed it!  Sort of expensive to make but absolutely worth every penny.  Makes a lot!

Timid w/ anchovies, I LOVED this recipe! I was hesitant because of silken tofu also, but Alton Brown knocks one outta the park with this delight! My girlfriend raves about this all the time. A definite must-have for your recipe book.

I have been making this dressing for several years. It's the one I take to work, leave in the fridge and use a good-sized dollop on my salads every day.

As one reviewer said, it can be garlic-y. I use only 1 clove and sometimes that's strong. When I used the minced garlic from the jar, I use about 1/4 tsp. I'm also lazy and round up on the white wine vinegar & worchestershire to a scant 1 tablespoon so I don't need to dirty another measuring spoon. And I rarely add the salt & pepper. When I have anchovy paste, I add it.

I'm curious about the review that said it didn't stay fresh. I keep it in the fridge and use it over a few weeks and never noticed a "freshness" issue.

I love tofu, but this didn't really do it for me. The raw garlic was very very strong and really overpowered the dressing. I would suggest using a quarter of the amount and tasting it before you add more.
Holy crap, this dressing tastes just like traditional caesar.  Very creamy and garlicky.  I will definitely be making this on a regular basis.  Alton, you are a food wizard!
Added a touch of lemon juice & anchovies -- my dinner group couldn't guess the base was tofu.

This is delicious. Like others, I added tinned anchovies to the blend. I served it to people that I don't think would ever eat tofu... Also great for those who can't do raw eggs (one of my friends is pregnant). I had firm tofu on hand, and I just thinned it a little with milk. It was just great!
I haven't made this recipe yet, but it sounds wonderful.  I really would like to see a nutritional breakdown of it.
This was excellent.  The flavors are spot on.  You couldn't ask for a better Caesar, and the benefits of the tofu are awesome.

I kept the ingredients as is but added a generous squeeze of fresh lemon juice and about a one-inch strip of anchovy paste.  I also used Parmigiano Reggiano which was worth the expense.  Some homemade rustic loaf croutons and they were weeping in the aisles...
Delicious! This was one of the best recipes I've tried for homemade Caesar dressing. The tofu makes it wonderfully creamy, and the "no guilt" title really does apply
An excellent recipe, but it doesn't stay fresh more than a couple of days, so use it fast!  Perfect for my low-carb lifestyle.

Very good and healthy recipe.  I wouldn't have known there was tofu in there unless someone told me.  I tried using powdered mustard instead of dijon (that's what I had), but it didn't work ask well.  Overall though it came out well.  The real mustard certainly would have added more kick to this dressing.
Very good salad dressing with a unique flavor. Good job Alton!

I may never make regular caesar salad dressing again! This is some of the best caesar dressing I've ever made... and it keeps really well with no risk of food-borne illness. You can't beat it. A winner and a crowd-pleasing hit.

This is one of those great recipes that comes out exactly as it should when you follow the directions.  Very delicious!! I was suprised, but very pleased with the way it came out.  Can't wait to serve this to friends without letting on about the tofu!!
Have made this dressing many times and love the fact it is low calorie and very tasty.

video.name: Perfect Caesar Salad Dressing
video.description: Healthy and tasty, create a perfect Caesar salad dressing without eggs.
